elements.content: Many metal–organic frameworks have been designed and synthesized for biosensors because of high surface area and porosity, suitable size, and good biocompatibility. Despite recent advances, however, most of them are only used as a nanocarrier. In this work, a new artificial nanozyme was constructed on a metalloporphyrinic metal–organic framework (PMOF­(Fe)), which was formed by Fe porphyrin and Zr4+ ions. Then, ultrasmall Pt nanoparticles (Pt NPs) were loaded on the surface of PMOF­(Fe) to form Pt@PMOF­(Fe). Because of the high surface area and exposed Fe activity center, PMOF­(Fe) works as a nanocarrier to hinder the Pt NP aggregation and exhibits high peroxidase-mimicking activity. Hence, Pt NPs decorated on the surface of PMOF­(Fe) possessed high stability and exhibited high activity. Due to the synergistic effect between PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs, Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibits superior catalase- and peroxidase-like activities. Moreover, Pt@PMOF­(Fe) possesses high electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of H2O2 and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). This strategy may serve as a strong foundation to design MOF-based artificial nanozymes and develop an ideal platform for MOFs and nanozymes toward artificial enzymatic catalytic systems, fuel cells and new analytical applications.

elements.content: Recently, artificial enzymes with low-cost synthesis, adjustable catalytic activity, high stability, and ease of recycling and reuse have drawn increasing attention. Owing to these advantages, artificial enzymes have been used in widespread applications such as sensors, cancer treatment, and catalysis. To date, a lot of nanomaterials, such as iron oxide materials (Fe3O4, Fe2O3); Mn3O4; carbon dots; graphitic carbon nitride (g-CN); Ag; Pd; Au; Pt; multimetallic NPs; metal–organic framework (MOF); and Cu@Cu2O aerogel networks, have been used for mimetic enzymes. Owing to their adjustable size, morphology and catalytic activity, these nanozymes were widely employed in biosensors, therapeutics and immunoassay. However, most nanomaterial-based enzymes generally have some drawbacks, including complicated immobilization procedure, difficulty in modification, easy aggregation and on addition of extra media in an electrochemical sensor, leading to impede their extensive application. To enlarge the scope of application, some nanoparticles were assembled or modified on the surface of nanomaterials. For example, Fe3O4–AuNPs anchored on the surface of 2D MOF nanosheets show enhanced peroxidase-like activity. GOx and NiPd were modified on ZIF-8 and used as an artificial enzyme for tandem catalysis. However, 2D MOF nanosheets or ZIF-8 in the above systems were just applied as the nanocarrier and their catalytic properties have not been used. On the other hand, the electrode modified with enzymes is a good model to understand the mechanism of enzymatic reactions, to find the interactions between the catalytic performance and structure, and to provide the information about detection. In electrochemical biosensors, the transport of the target to the enzyme active site and the charge transport between the electrode and substrates play an important role in signal amplification and enzyme reaction. However, some available enzymes used in electrochemical biosensors are unstable on the electrode and are hardly applied to amplify signals. Therefore, development of nanomaterials with a synergistic effect, electronic properties, and multiple enzyme mimetic ability to simulate complex enzyme reactions is of significant current interest.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, artificial enzymes with low-cost synthesis, adjustable catalytic activity, high stability, and ease of recycling and reuse have drawn increasing attention. Owing to these advantages, artificial enzymes have been used in widespread applications such as sensors, cancer treatment, and catalysis. To date, a lot of nanomaterials, such as iron oxide materials (Fe3O4, Fe2O3); Mn3O4; carbon dots; graphitic carbon nitride (g-CN); Ag; Pd; Au; Pt; multimetallic NPs; metal-organic framework (MOF); and Cu@Cu2O aerogel networks, have been used for mimetic enzymes. Owing to their adjustable size, morphology and catalytic activity, these nanozymes were widely employed in biosensors, therapeutics and immunoassay. However, most nanomaterial-based enzymes generally have some drawbacks, including complicated immobilization procedure, difficulty in modification, easy aggregation and on addition of extra media in an electrochemical sensor, leading to impede their extensive application. To enlarge the scope of application, some nanoparticles were assembled or modified on the surface of nanomaterials. For example, Fe3O4-AuNPs anchored on the surface of 2D MOF nanosheets show enhanced peroxidase-like activity. GOx and NiPd were modified on ZIF-8 and used as an artificial enzyme for tandem catalysis. However, 2D MOF nanosheets or ZIF-8 in the above systems were just applied as the nanocarrier and their catalytic properties have not been used. On the other hand, the electrode modified with enzymes is a good model to understand the mechanism of enzymatic reactions, to find the interactions between the catalytic performance and structure, and to provide the information about detection. In electrochemical biosensors, the transport of the target to the enzyme active site and the charge transport between the electrode and substrates play an important role in signal amplification and enzyme reaction. However, some available enzymes used in electrochemical biosensors are unstable on the electrode and are hardly applied to amplify signals. Therefore, development of nanomaterials with a synergistic effect, electronic properties, and multiple enzyme mimetic ability to simulate complex enzyme reactions is of significant current interest.

elements.content: Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as a blooming alternative material, which are composed of metal ions as a node and organic ligands as a linker, have captured widespread attention, due to their diversified and tailorable structures, high surface area and porosity, exposed active sites, and good biocompatibility. To date, MOFs have been used in diverse applications, such as PDT, catalysis, gas storage and separations, and many others. Particularly, MOFs that were formed with metalloporphyrines as linkers and/or modified with natural enzymes have been used as enzymes in bioanalysis and biocatalysts. However, they can be only employed to mimic one kind of enzymes. Although, various MOF-supported biomolecule or metal nanoparticles have been used in electrochemical sensors or electrocatalysis, which only acted as a nanocarrier and the instinct property had not been employed. Thus, to exploit the intrinsic activity of MOFs in multifunctional biomimetic catalysis, the amplification signal is urgently required to design an easy strategy.

To date, MOFs have been used in diverse applications, such as PDT, catalysis, gas storage and separations, and many others. Particularly, MOFs that were formed with metalloporphyrines as linkers and/or modified with natural enzymes have been used as enzymes in bioanalysis and biocatalysts. However, they can be only employed to mimic one kind of enzymes. Although, various MOF-supported biomolecule or metal nanoparticles have been used in electrochemical sensors or electrocatalysis, which only acted as a nanocarrier and the instinct property had not been employed. Thus, to exploit the intrinsic activity of MOFs in multifunctional biomimetic catalysis, the amplification signal is urgently required to design an easy strategy.

elements.content: Inspired by the multiple functions of the multienzyme system, we present a simple strategy for preparing MOFs and decorating them with Pt NPs as an artificial enzyme (). The MOFs (PMOF­(Fe)) were constructed from metalloporphyrin (FeTCPP) and Zr. It is known that FeTCPP is a kind of metalloporphyrin and used as a mimetic enzyme in biosensors. After obtaining PMOF­(Fe), Pt NPs were modified on the surface of PMOF­(Fe) to form Pt@PMOF­(Fe). In the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) complex, PMOF­(Fe) not only acted as a nanocarrier but also possessed peroxidase-like activity; in addition, PMOF­(Fe) could prevent Pt NP aggregation, resulting in maintaining and increasing the stability of Pt NPs. Furthermore, Pt NPs exhibited catalase- and peroxidase-like activities. Hence, Pt@PMOF­(Fe) possesses high catalase- and peroxidase-like activities and could catalyze the oxidation of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and o-phenyldiamine (OPD). On the other hand, when Pt@PMOF­(Fe) was modified on the electrode, Pt NPs could reduce H2O2 and facilitate the electron transfer between the electrode and the Fe active center in the presence of H2O2, generating an enhanced electrochemical signal. Furthermore, the results of electrochemical activity showed that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) also has the high electrocatalytic activity toward the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Furthermore, owing to the synergy between PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs, the electrochemical signal could be improved.

elements.content: Hexadecyltrimethylammonium zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O), benzoic acid, sodium borohydride (NaBH4), o-phenylenediamine (OPD), 1-(3-(dimethylamino)­propyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC, ≥98%), N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai, China). Iron­(III) meso-5,10,15,20-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin chloride (FeTCPP) was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Phosphate buffer (0.1 M, pH 7.4) was used as electrolyte solution. All buffers were prepared with Millipore Milli-Q water (≥18.2 MΩ cm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Reagents

Hexadecyltrimethylammonium zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2⋅8H2O), benzoic acid, sodium borohydride (NaBH4), o-phenylenediamine (OPD), 1-(3-(dimethylamino)propyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC, ≥98%), N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai, China). Iron(III) meso-5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin chloride (FeTCPP) was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Phosphate buffer (0.1 M, pH 7.4) was used as electrolyte solution. All buffers were prepared with Millipore Milli-Q water (≥18.2 MΩ cm).

elements.content: UV–vis spectroscopy was performed using a Hitachi U-3900 UV/vis spectrometer (Hitachi, Japan). Transmission electron microscopy images were obtained on using HT-7700. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using an S-4800 scanning electron microscope (Hitachi, Japan). X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using Shimadzu XRD-6000 (Shimadzu Co., Japan). PHI 5000 Versa Probe (UlVAC-PHI Co., Japan.) was used to perform X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). A CHI 760D electrochemical workstation (Shanghai CH Instruments, China) with a three-electrode system, which comprises a Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode, a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) as the working electrode, was used for testing cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV).

Apparatus

PHI 5000 Versa Probe (UlVAC-PHI Co., Japan.) was used to perform X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). A CHI 760D electrochemical workstation (Shanghai CH Instruments, China) with a three-electrode system, which comprises a Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode, a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) as the working electrode, was used for testing cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV).

elements.content: In a Teflon liner, FeTCPP (6.0 mg), ZrOCl2·8H2O (90 mg), and benzoic acid (840 mg) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL) and then sonicated for 10 min. Subsequently, the Teflon liner was heated at 80 °C for 5 h. The product was washed with DMF and ethanol. Finally, the obtained PMOF­(Fe) was redispersed in ethanol.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PMOF(Fe)

In a Teflon liner, FeTCPP (6.0 mg), ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (90 mg), and benzoic acid (840 mg) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL) and then sonicated for 10 min. Subsequently, the Teflon liner was heated at 80 °C for 5 h. The product was washed with DMF and ethanol. Finally, the obtained PMOF(Fe) was redispersed in ethanol.

elements.content: The synthesis of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) was similar to that mentioned in the previous report. After adding H2PtCl6 (200 μL, 10 mM) and PMOF­(Fe) (50 μL, 4 mg mL–1) into 5 mL of H2O with stirring for 20 min, 1 mL of NaBH4 (2 mg mL–1) was added to the reactor and stirred for another 30 min, followed by washing with H2O to obtain Pt@PMOF­(Fe).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Pt@PMOF(Fe)

The synthesis of Pt@PMOF(Fe) was similar to that mentioned in the previous report. After adding H2PtCl6 (200 μL, 10 mM) and PMOF(Fe) (50 μL, 4 mg mL-1) into 5 mL of H2O with stirring for 20 min, 1 mL of NaBH4 (2 mg mL-1) was added to the reactor and stirred for another 30 min, followed by washing with H2O to obtain Pt@PMOF(Fe).

elements.content: The catalase-like activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) in PBS was determined using hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as the substrate, which could be decomposed by Pt@PMOF­(Fe) to form oxygen (O2). The solutions in the tubes containing (1) H2O2 (5.0 mM), (2) PMOF­(Fe) (1.0 mg mL–1) + H2O2 (5.0 mM), (3) Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (1.0 mg mL–1) + H2O2 (5.0 mM), and (4) catalase (20 μg mL–1) + H2O2 (5.0 mM) were reacted at 37 °C for 30 min, and the photos were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Catalase-Like Activity of Pt@PMOF(Fe)

The catalase-like activity of Pt@PMOF(Fe) in PBS was determined using hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as the substrate, which could be decomposed by Pt@PMOF(Fe) to form oxygen (O2). The solutions in the tubes containing (1) H2O2 (5.0 mM), (2) PMOF(Fe) (1.0 mg mL-1) + H2O2 (5.0 mM), (3) Pt@PMOF(Fe) (1.0 mg mL-1) + H2O2 (5.0 mM), and (4) catalase (20 μg mL-1) + H2O2 (5.0 mM) were reacted at 37 °C for 30 min, and the photos were obtained.

elements.content: The H2O2 decomposition experiments were studied by adding PMOF­(Fe) or Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (1.0 mg mL–1) into PBS at 37 °C for different time periods, and then the absorbance was measured at 240 nm on a lambda-35 UV–vis spectrophotometer.

elements.content: As shown in A, PMOF­(Fe) was prepared by the reaction of ZrOCl2·8H2O and FeTCPP at 80 °C for 5 h via one step. Then, the PMOF­(Fe) acted as a nanocarrier for in situ grown Pt NPs via PMOF­(Fe) and H2PtCl6 solution mixed with fresh NaBH4 at room temperature. The prepared Pt@PMOF­(Fe) was used as a biomimetic catalyst for the oxidation of OPD and an electrode material for the reduction of H2O2 and O2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

As shown in A, PMOF(Fe) was prepared by the reaction of ZrOCl2⋅8H2O and FeTCPP at 80 °C for 5 h via one step. Then, the PMOF(Fe) acted as a nanocarrier for in situ grown Pt NPs via PMOF(Fe) and H2PtCl6 solution mixed with fresh NaBH4 at room temperature. The prepared Pt@PMOF(Fe) was used as a biomimetic catalyst for the oxidation of OPD and an electrode material for the reduction of H2O2 and O2.

elements.content: The obtained PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) were first examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The low-magnification SEM images revealed that PMOF­(Fe) was of uniform ellipsoidal shape with an average diameter of 300 nm (A). TEM images in B further show the morphology and size of PMOF­(Fe), which was consistent with the result of SEM. After modifying the Pt NPs on the surface of PMOF­(Fe), Pt@PMOF­(Fe) kept the morphology of PMOF­(Fe) (C) and with a lot of Pt NPs. The size of Pt NPs is around 2 nm (D, inset). These Pt NPs were modified on the surface of PMOF­(Fe) uniformly. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) indicated the lattice spacing of Pt NPs is 0.224 nm, which is the (111) facet of Pt NPs (D, inset). The SEM elemental mapping showed the presence of Pt elements in the Pt@PMOF­(Fe), which also indicated that Pt NPs were decorated on the surface of PMOF­(Fe) with a good distribution (Figure S1). In addition, the elemental Pt in Pt@PMOF­(Fe) was further verified by energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), which is shown in Figure S2. These results indicated that Pt NPs were formed successfully on PMOF­(Fe). The above results proved that the preparation of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) is successful.

elements.content: To gain insight into the microstructure and composition of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe), the X-ray diffraction (XRD) of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) was measured. The diffraction peaks of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) at 4.80, 7.08 and 9.67° are the characteristic peaks, which could be indexed to (−220), (410), and (−150), respectively, indicating the PMOF­(Fe) formed (A). Noteworthily, the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibited peaks between 40 and 80° (A, curve b), which were assigned to Pt NPs (JCPDS: 65-2868), implying that the Pt NPs were formed on the surface of PMOF­(Fe). These results show that the structure of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could be consistent with that of PMOF­(Fe), indicating that the structure of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs could be maintained after their hybridization. Besides, to further verify the synthesis of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) successfully, X-ray photon spectroscopy (XPS) was employed. According to B, curve a, the PMOF­(Fe) is composed of Fe, O, C, N, and Zr. From B, curve b, the appearance of the Pt elemental peak at 100 eV shows that Pt NPs were formed, which corresponds to the result of TEM, EDS, and XRD. Thus, these characterizations reveal the successful synthesis of Pt@PMOF­(Fe).

elements.content: First, the catalase-like activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) was investigated, where H2O2 was used, which could be decomposed by catalase to generate oxygen (O2), leading to a gas bubble formation. As revealed in Figure S3, compared with the system of H2O2–PMOF­(Fe) (image b), more gas bubbles produced in tubes containing H2O2 and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (image c), proving that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) had higher catalase-like activity than that of PMOF­(Fe). In PMOF­(Fe), FeTCPP as a linker, which is an iron porphyrin species, could mimic horseradish peroxidase (HRP). Due to H2O2 as the sole substrate, the catalase activity of FeTCPP is weak, which could protect the active center against inactivation. Thus, there are little gas bubbles in the tube containing H2O2 and PMOF­(Fe). On the other hand, the gas bubble production in the H2O2–Pt@PMOF­(Fe) system is similar to that in the system of catalase and H2O2 (image d). These results showed that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) has the catalase-like activity, due to the formed Pt NPs.
elements.clean_text:
Catalase-Like Activity of Pt@PMOF(Fe)

First, the catalase-like activity of Pt@PMOF(Fe) was investigated, where H2O2 was used, which could be decomposed by catalase to generate oxygen (O2), leading to a gas bubble formation. As revealed in Figure S3, compared with the system of H2O2-PMOF(Fe) (image b), more gas bubbles produced in tubes containing H2O2 and Pt@PMOF(Fe) (image c), proving that Pt@PMOF(Fe) had higher catalase-like activity than that of PMOF(Fe). In PMOF(Fe), FeTCPP as a linker, which is an iron porphyrin species, could mimic horseradish peroxidase (HRP). Due to H2O2 as the sole substrate, the catalase activity of FeTCPP is weak, which could protect the active center against inactivation. Thus, there are little gas bubbles in the tube containing H2O2 and PMOF(Fe). On the other hand, the gas bubble production in the H2O2-Pt@PMOF(Fe) system is similar to that in the system of catalase and H2O2 (image d). These results showed that Pt@PMOF(Fe) has the catalase-like activity, due to the formed Pt NPs.

elements.content: UV–visible spectroscopy was conducted to monitor H2O2 oxidation by PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe), providing evidence for H2O2 oxidation (Figures S4 and ). It can be seen in Figure S4 that the absorbance of H2O2 at 240 nm in the system of Pt@PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2 (curve b) was lower than that in the system of PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2 (curve a) and the system of Pt NPs–H2O2 (curve c), suggesting that the catalytic activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward oxidation of H2O2 is much higher than that of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs. With an increase in time, the concentration of H2O2 changed negligibly in the system of PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2 (A), while the changes were significant in the presence of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (B), indicating Pt@PMOF­(Fe) with high catalase-like activity toward the oxidation of H2O2, which are consistent with the result of gas bubbles. Driven by the Pt NPs formed on PMOF­(Fe) uniformly and stably, H2O2 could be oxidized easily via locating on the bridge Pt–Pt site to form Pt–OH bonds; meanwhile, the Fe center in PMOF­(Fe) could act as an electron donor for Pt and as a center for the generation of Fe–OH to reduce the Pt–OH bond strength. Thus, the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) has high activity for decomposing H2O2. At the same time, for the oxidation of H2O2, time-dependent absorption spectra were performed to study the performances of the catalytic activity of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe). When H2O2 was added in the PMOF­(Fe) system, the absorbance at 240 nm and the rates of oxidation were changed negligibly with an increase in time and concentration of H2O2 (Figure S5). In contrast, the absorbance at 240 nm varied with an increase in time and the reaction rates increased along with the concentration of H2O2 in the system containing Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (Figure S6). These results supported that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibited excellent activity toward the oxidation of H2O2. In addition, a good stability is important to ensure that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could be used in harsh conditions, so the effects of pH and temperature on the catalytic activity of catalase and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) were further studied. The results in Figure S7 showed that the catalytic activity of catalase changed with different pH values, while the effects of pH for Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could be neglected. When catalase and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) catalyzed H2O2 at different temperatures in PBS (pH 7.4), respectively, catalase lost its catalytic activity at high temperature, while Pt@PMOF­(Fe) showed little change at the different temperature (Figure S8). The XRD result shows that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could maintain good stability after reacting with H2O2 (Figure S9). Overall, these results demonstrated that compared with PMOF­(Fe), Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibited excellent stability for oxidizing H2O2 to produce O2 in harsh conditions.

elements.content: The Michaelis constant (K m) obtained via nonlinear Hill function simulation was used to further gain insight into the peroxidase-like activity of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) in the presence of OPD and H2O2. As shown in Figure S12B, the K m of OPD in the PMOF­(Fe) system is 7.81 mM, which is lower than that of zirconium–metalloporphyrin (PCN-222) (8.92 mM) as mimic peroxidase, due to the small size of PMOF­(Fe) in comparison with PCN-222. For the OPD oxidation reaction, Pt@PMOF­(Fe) possessed smaller K m with 0.886 mM (B) than PMOF­(Fe) and magnetic zeolitic imidazolate framework 8 (mZIF-8) (2.42 mM), indicating that Pt NPs could enhance the catalytic activity of PMOF­(Fe). All of these results showed that owing to the synergetic effect between PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs, Pt@PMOF­(Fe) possesses higher peroxidase-like activity.

elements.content: It is worth mentioning that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibited electrocatalytic performance for H2O2. To confirm the electrocatalytic properties of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward the reduction of H2O2, the cyclic voltammograms (CV) of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) in the absence and presence of H2O2 were studied. As shown in , there is a cathodic wave at −0.2 V in the absence of H2O2 (curve a), which is corresponding to the electrocatalytic reduction of O2. Upon addition H2O2, a reduction peak at −0.45 V was observed, indicating that the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could catalyze the reduction of H2O2 (curve b). Figure S13 shows the CV of PMOF­(Fe) in the absence of H2O2 (curve a) and in the presence of H2O2 (curve b). The reduction potential observed in the presence of H2O2 (curve b) is lower than that observed in the absence of H2O2, which proves the formation of a stable porphyrin π cation radical, demonstrating the PMOF­(Fe) with the electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of H2O2. The current is enhanced in the system Pt@PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2, which is mainly because the PMOF­(Fe) with large surface could anchor more Pt NPs, and then Pt NPs could increase the conductivity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) for electrocatalysis on one hand. On the other hand, Pt NPs formed on PMOF­(Fe) uniformly and the PMOF­(Fe) with the exposed active center could improve the catalyst activity for the reduction of H2O2. In terms of the synergetic effect, Fe­(III) in PMOF­(Fe) acts as a promoting center for the generation of a ferryl species (Fe­(IV) = O), as a porphyrin radical cation and as an electron donor to Pt NPs. The high interface between Pt NPs and PMOF­(Fe) in Pt@PMOF­(Fe) and the H2O2 adsorbed on the PMOF­(Fe) could promote H2O2 activation on the most acidic Fe3+ Lewis sites in proximity to Pt sites, which could decrease the Pt 4f binding energies and Pt–OH bond strength, so electrochemical activity toward H2O2 could be promoted. The catalytic process of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) immobilized on the electrode surface could be expressed as follows 2 Pt + H 2 O 2 → 2 Pt ( OH ) 2 Pt ( OH ) + 2 H + + 2 e − → 2 Pt ( H 2 O ) Fe III + H 2 O 2 → Fe IV · + = O + H 2 O Fe IV · + = O + e − → Fe IV = O Fe IV = O + e − + 2 H + → Fe III + H 2 O First, H2O2 was formed adsorbing OH species and adsorbed on the surface of Pt. Because the adsorbed OH on Pt is not stable, the surface sites could be regenerated in the reduction step, and then the free Pt sites could dissociate other H2O2. At the same time, H2O2 is reduced by FeTCPP (FeIII resting state) to form H2O and compound I ( Fe IV · + = O, which includes FeIV = O and a porphyrin π cation radical). Then, the compound I was reduced via one electron transfer from the electrode to form compound II (ferryl (FeIV = O)). With continued charged propagation, compound II was converted back to its resting ferric state accompanying the uptake of two protons and the formation of a water molecule.

elements.content: Furthermore, the electrocatalytic activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) snowflake toward different concentrations of H2O2 was examined via cyclic voltammetry (CV). As shown in , the reduction current at −0.45 V increased on increasing the H2O2 concentration, suggesting that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could electrocatalyze toward the reduction of H2O2. Moreover, there is a good linear relationship between the reduction current and the concentration of H2O2 from 0 to 10 mM, which is wider than that of H2O2 sensor using Ag@Cu NW (1.0–10 mM) and 3D microsnowflake structured Fe2O3 (0.1–5.5 mM) as electrocatalytic materials. The detection limit was 6.0 μM at a signal-to-noise ratio of 3. The selectivity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward the reduction of H2O2 was assessed with a variety of interfering species, including 2.0 mM glucose, 2.0 mM urea acid (UA), 2.0 mM ascorbic acid (AA), and 2.0 mM bisphenol A (BPA). The results showed that all of the interfering species had negligible current change, whereas the current changed remarkably in the presence of H2O2 (Figure S14). It indicates that the current could remain 91% after storing for 7 days at 4 °C, when the biosensor was not used (Figure S15). These results proved the excellent electrocatalytic activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward H2O2 with excellent selectivity and could be employed for the detection of H2O2 in complex samples.

elements.content: In general, iron porphyrins in the active center of cytochrome coenzymes oxidase and heme-containing enzymes were used as the catalysts for the reduction of O2. Until now, many catalysts based on the porphyrins and their derivatives mimicking the coenzyme have been investigated for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The electrocatalytic activity of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward O2 was also investigated (Figure S1). Compared with in N2-saturated PBS, both PMOF­(Fe)/GCE and Pt@PMOF­(Fe)/GCE have excellent current signal in O2-saturated PBS, demonstrating that PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) have the electrocatalytic activity toward ORR. The enhancement in the electrochemical signal is attributed to the linker, FeTCPP, which acted as a catalyst in the electrochemical reduction processes. In addition, the FeTCPP has high activity for ORR with four-electron reduction. Moreover, the peak current with Pt@PMOF­(Fe)/GCE in O2-saturated PBS (Figure S16B, curve b) is higher than that with PMOF­(Fe) in O2-saturated PBS (Figure S16A, curve b). This performance increase can be attributed to the modified Pt NPs, which could be acted as a catalyst for ORR with four-electron reduction of O2 to H2O. In addition, in the process of ORR, the electron was transferred form the Fe center to O2 to form intermediate Fe­(IV), and the Pt NPs could replenish electron to Fe­(IV) to protect Fe leaching. Thus, owing to the synergy between PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs, the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) electrochemically active sites and surface area for O2 reduction could be significantly increased. The mechanism should be divided into different steps and described as follows M − Pt + O 2 + e − → O 2 − M − Pt O 2 − M − Pt + H + + e − → HOO − M − Pt HOO − M − Pt + H + + e − → O − M − Pt + H 2 O Fe III + e − → Fe II Fe II + O 2 → Fe II − O 2 Fe II − O 2 + 4 e − + 4 H + → Fe III + H 2 O Here, M is the chemical active site on Pt. In and , oxygen reacts with the surface of Pt NPs via accepting an electron from the Pt NPs. In the reaction process, Pt sites exert electronic effects. For , in PMOF­(Fe), the Fe active center with more electropositive could provide an electrostatic force that is more favorable for the electrochemical reaction. Thus, is enhanced. At the same time, FeIII was reduced to form FeII via obtaining an electron from the electrode. Then, the formed FeII reacted rapidly with oxygen to produce FeII–O2, which could be directly reduced at the electrode. Thus, the catalytic activity for O2 reduction is enhanced.

In general, iron porphyrins in the active center of cytochrome coenzymes oxidase and heme-containing enzymes were used as the catalysts for the reduction of O2. Until now, many catalysts based on the porphyrins and their derivatives mimicking the coenzyme have been investigated for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The electrocatalytic activity of PMOF(Fe) and Pt@PMOF(Fe) toward O2 was also investigated (Figure S1). Compared with in N2-saturated PBS, both PMOF(Fe)/GCE and Pt@PMOF(Fe)/GCE have excellent current signal in O2-saturated PBS, demonstrating that PMOF(Fe) and Pt@PMOF(Fe) have the electrocatalytic activity toward ORR. The enhancement in the electrochemical signal is attributed to the linker, FeTCPP, which acted as a catalyst in the electrochemical reduction processes. In addition, the FeTCPP has high activity for ORR with four-electron reduction. Moreover, the peak current with Pt@PMOF(Fe)/GCE in O2-saturated PBS (Figure S16B, curve b) is higher than that with PMOF(Fe) in O2-saturated PBS (Figure S16A, curve b). This performance increase can be attributed to the modified Pt NPs, which could be acted as a catalyst for ORR with four-electron reduction of O2 to H2O. In addition, in the process of ORR, the electron was transferred form the Fe center to O2 to form intermediate Fe(IV), and the Pt NPs could replenish electron to Fe(IV) to protect Fe leaching. Thus, owing to the synergy between PMOF(Fe) and Pt NPs, the Pt@PMOF(Fe) electrochemically active sites and surface area for O2 reduction could be significantly increased. The mechanism should be divided into different steps and described as follows  6    M - Pt +   O   2   +   e   -   →   O   2   - M - Pt     7      O   2   - M - Pt +   H   +   +   e   -   → HOO - M - Pt     8    HOO - M - Pt +   H   +   +   e   -   → O - M - Pt +   H   2   O     9      Fe   III   + e - →   Fe   II       10      Fe   II   +   O   2   →   Fe   II   -   O   2       11      Fe   II   -   O   2   + 4   e   -   + 4   H   +   →   Fe   III   +   H   2   O   Here, M is the chemical active site on Pt. In  and , oxygen reacts with the surface of Pt NPs via accepting an electron from the Pt NPs. In the reaction process, Pt sites exert electronic effects. For , in PMOF(Fe), the Fe active center with more electropositive could provide an electrostatic force that is more favorable for the electrochemical reaction. Thus,  is enhanced. At the same time, FeIII was reduced to form FeII via obtaining an electron from the electrode. Then, the formed FeII reacted rapidly with oxygen to produce FeII-O2, which could be directly reduced at the electrode. Thus, the catalytic activity for O2 reduction is enhanced.

elements.content: In summary, a multifunctional artificial enzyme via modifying Pt NPs on the metalloporphyrin MOF was synthesized using a simple method. The PMOF­(Fe) with large surface area not only acted as a carrier but also exhibited a high biomimetic catalytic activity. Pt NPs in situ grown on the surface of the PMOF­(Fe) demonstrated catalase-like activity to enhance the oxidation of H2O2. When applied in electrocatalysis, due to the synergy between PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs, the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) modified electrode offers high activities toward to the reduction of H2O2, which could be used for H2O2 sensor without adding redox mediators. Furthermore, the Pt NPs with porphyrin in PMOF­(Fe) could afford ORR in PBS, which has the potential for fuel cells and biofuel cells, especially in cancer diagnosis. This system provides a route to exploit the self-biomimetic catalytic performance of MOFs and tune the catalytic activity of artificial enzymes, which offers a novel strategy to apply the artificial nanozyme in a biosensor or energy device.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a multifunctional artificial enzyme via modifying Pt NPs on the metalloporphyrin MOF was synthesized using a simple method. The PMOF(Fe) with large surface area not only acted as a carrier but also exhibited a high biomimetic catalytic activity. Pt NPs in situ grown on the surface of the PMOF(Fe) demonstrated catalase-like activity to enhance the oxidation of H2O2. When applied in electrocatalysis, due to the synergy between PMOF(Fe) and Pt NPs, the Pt@PMOF(Fe) modified electrode offers high activities toward to the reduction of H2O2, which could be used for H2O2 sensor without adding redox mediators. Furthermore, the Pt NPs with porphyrin in PMOF(Fe) could afford ORR in PBS, which has the potential for fuel cells and biofuel cells, especially in cancer diagnosis. This system provides a route to exploit the self-biomimetic catalytic performance of MOFs and tune the catalytic activity of artificial enzymes, which offers a novel strategy to apply the artificial nanozyme in a biosensor or energy device.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PMOF(Fe)

In a Teflon liner, FeTCPP (6.0 mg), ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (90 mg), and benzoic acid (840 mg) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL) and then sonicated for 10 min. Subsequently, the Teflon liner was heated at 80 °C for 5 h. The product was washed with DMF and ethanol. Finally, the obtained PMOF(Fe) was redispersed in ethanol.

cln_elements.content:
UV–visible spectroscopy was conducted to monitor H2O2 oxidation by PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe), providing evidence for H2O2 oxidation (Figures S4 and ). It can be seen in Figure S4 that the absorbance of H2O2 at 240 nm in the system of Pt@PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2 (curve b) was lower than that in the system of PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2 (curve a) and the system of Pt NPs–H2O2 (curve c), suggesting that the catalytic activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward oxidation of H2O2 is much higher than that of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt NPs. With an increase in time, the concentration of H2O2 changed negligibly in the system of PMOF­(Fe)–H2O2 (A), while the changes were significant in the presence of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (B), indicating Pt@PMOF­(Fe) with high catalase-like activity toward the oxidation of H2O2, which are consistent with the result of gas bubbles. Driven by the Pt NPs formed on PMOF­(Fe) uniformly and stably, H2O2 could be oxidized easily via locating on the bridge Pt–Pt site to form Pt–OH bonds; meanwhile, the Fe center in PMOF­(Fe) could act as an electron donor for Pt and as a center for the generation of Fe–OH to reduce the Pt–OH bond strength. Thus, the Pt@PMOF­(Fe) has high activity for decomposing H2O2. At the same time, for the oxidation of H2O2, time-dependent absorption spectra were performed to study the performances of the catalytic activity of PMOF­(Fe) and Pt@PMOF­(Fe). When H2O2 was added in the PMOF­(Fe) system, the absorbance at 240 nm and the rates of oxidation were changed negligibly with an increase in time and concentration of H2O2 (Figure S5). In contrast, the absorbance at 240 nm varied with an increase in time and the reaction rates increased along with the concentration of H2O2 in the system containing Pt@PMOF­(Fe) (Figure S6). These results supported that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibited excellent activity toward the oxidation of H2O2. In addition, a good stability is important to ensure that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could be used in harsh conditions, so the effects of pH and temperature on the catalytic activity of catalase and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) were further studied. The results in Figure S7 showed that the catalytic activity of catalase changed with different pH values, while the effects of pH for Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could be neglected. When catalase and Pt@PMOF­(Fe) catalyzed H2O2 at different temperatures in PBS (pH 7.4), respectively, catalase lost its catalytic activity at high temperature, while Pt@PMOF­(Fe) showed little change at the different temperature (Figure S8). The XRD result shows that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could maintain good stability after reacting with H2O2 (Figure S9). Overall, these results demonstrated that compared with PMOF­(Fe), Pt@PMOF­(Fe) exhibited excellent stability for oxidizing H2O2 to produce O2 in harsh conditions.

Furthermore, the electrocatalytic activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) snowflake toward different concentrations of H2O2 was examined via cyclic voltammetry (CV). As shown in , the reduction current at −0.45 V increased on increasing the H2O2 concentration, suggesting that Pt@PMOF­(Fe) could electrocatalyze toward the reduction of H2O2. Moreover, there is a good linear relationship between the reduction current and the concentration of H2O2 from 0 to 10 mM, which is wider than that of H2O2 sensor using Ag@Cu NW (1.0–10 mM) and 3D microsnowflake structured Fe2O3 (0.1–5.5 mM) as electrocatalytic materials. The detection limit was 6.0 μM at a signal-to-noise ratio of 3. The selectivity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward the reduction of H2O2 was assessed with a variety of interfering species, including 2.0 mM glucose, 2.0 mM urea acid (UA), 2.0 mM ascorbic acid (AA), and 2.0 mM bisphenol A (BPA). The results showed that all of the interfering species had negligible current change, whereas the current changed remarkably in the presence of H2O2 (Figure S14). It indicates that the current could remain 91% after storing for 7 days at 4 °C, when the biosensor was not used (Figure S15). These results proved the excellent electrocatalytic activity of Pt@PMOF­(Fe) toward H2O2 with excellent selectivity and could be employed for the detection of H2O2 in complex samples.
